Normal.description: Lungs are healthy with no signs of abnormalities, infections, or tumors.

Benign.description: A non-cancerous growth or lesion in the lung.
Benign.guidance: While not harmful, it may require monitoring.

Malignant.description: Malignant lung cancer is the uncontrolled growth of abnormal cells in the lungs.
Malignant.guidance: Consult with an oncologist for a detailed diagnosis and treatment plan.

Benign.description: A benign skin lesion, such as a mole.
Benign.guidance: Regular monitoring is recommended, but no immediate treatment is necessary.

Malignant.description: Malignant melanoma is a type of skin cancer that begins in the melanocytes.
Malignant.guidance: Immediate consultation with a dermatologist or oncologist is recommended.

Benign.description: The blood cells are normal and show no signs of malignant transformation.

[Malignant] early Pre-B.description: Early-stage leukemia with abnormal Pre-B cells beginning to show growth.
[Malignant] early Pre-B.guidance: Consult a hematologist for further evaluation and treatment options.

[Malignant] Pre-B.description: An intermediate stage of leukemia where Pre-B cells have begun to spread into the bloodstream.
[Malignant] Pre-B.guidance: Immediate intervention and a treatment plan should be discussed with a hematologist.

[Malignant] Pro-B.description: An advanced stage of leukemia with aggressive proliferation of malignant B cells.
[Malignant] Pro-B.guidance: Consult with a hematologist-oncologist to begin treatment immediately.

Cyst.description: A fluid-filled sac that forms on the kidney, usually benign.
Cyst.guidance: Requires monitoring if they grow or cause symptoms.

Normal.description: The kidneys are healthy, with no signs of cysts, stones, or tumors.

Stone.description: A hard mass made of minerals that forms in the kidney.
Stone.guidance: Treatment options may include medication, hydration, or surgical removal.

Tumor.description: A mass in the kidney that can be benign or malignant.
Tumor.guidance: Immediate consultation with a nephrologist or oncologist is recommended.

Glioma.description: Gliomas are tumors that arise from glial cells in the brain or spinal cord.
Glioma.guidance: Consult with a neurologist or oncologist for further diagnosis.

Meningioma.description: A meningioma is a tumor that arises from the meninges.
Meningioma.guidance: While often benign, further tests are recommended to assess treatment options.

Pituitary.description: Pituitary tumors affect the pituitary gland, which controls hormones.
Pituitary.guidance: Consult an endocrinologist or neurosurgeon for further analysis.

No Tumor.description: No tumors or abnormal growths are present in the brain.
